topics.title: Cold open: Mihika’s reputation and ambition
topics.summary: Lenny shares that Mihika was the most-mentioned “best PM” on Twitter; Mihika frames her mindset as having world-sized scope and using prototyping to imagine the future. They tease Figma’s Maker Week as a driver of entrepreneurial culture.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Mihika’s background (FigJam early PM, new product launching in June, prior Meta and nonprofit work) and previews the episode’s focus: vision, buy-in, conviction, empathy/culture, and 0→1 execution inside a company.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Paragon (embedded integrations) and Lenny’s Job Board / recruiting service.

topics.title: Framing: strengths-based PMing and growth mindset
topics.summary: Lenny explains the “reverse performance review” format; Mihika describes her hybrid CS + visual arts background, why PM fits her, and the importance of leaning into spikes while still improving weaker areas.

topics.title: Crafting vision: anchor through chaos
topics.summary: Mihika argues vision is essential to navigate messy product development, keeping teams oriented through pivots and setbacks. She explains vision-building as cross-functional (research, design/prototyping, engineering feasibility) rather than linear.

topics.title: FigJam vision example: democratizing meetings
topics.summary: Using FigJam’s pandemic-era rise, Mihika shares how the team expanded from “brainstorms work well” to a broader vision: make many meeting types more democratic and participatory. This vision then informed features and rituals (templates, voting, music, kudos).

topics.title: How to deliver vision: one shared artifact
topics.summary: Mihika emphasizes aligning the team around a single combined deliverable (often a Figma deck) rather than separate readouts. Figma’s “see to believe” culture pushes teams to prototype early—even before green-lighting—to make the future feel real.

topics.title: Prototyping without skills: AI and asking for help
topics.summary: For PMs lacking design/engineering skills, Mihika suggests leveraging AI tools to lower the build barrier and proactively recruiting collaborators. She describes using Maker Week (internal hackathon) to assemble a team by directly asking coworkers to join.

topics.title: Building conviction fast: intuition and two-way doors
topics.summary: Mihika explains conviction as a momentum engine, grounded in Bezos’s two-way-door decisions and Meta’s “product sense.” She builds intuition via constant user conversations, shares the value of offering an initial hypothesis to provoke reactions, and stresses “strong opinions, weakly held.”

topics.title: Directness with trust: calibrating confidence and feedback
topics.summary: They discuss balancing strong opinions with team voice by explicitly signaling confidence levels and inviting disagreement. Mihika shares tactics for healthy directness: make it two-way, ask for feedback first, treat feedback as a continuous gift, and act on it quickly.

topics.title: Hype as a PM responsibility: internal momentum moments
topics.summary: Mihika describes “hacking hype” as monitoring organizational sentiment and creating visibility moments—especially for bottom-up 0→1 bets. She shares pushing for an early demo of her new product at SKO to rally the company and accelerate learning despite rough edges.

topics.title: External hype and delight: FigJam birthday launch
topics.summary: Mihika contrasts internal vs external hype and explains tailoring excitement to a product’s brand. She recounts FigJam’s one-year “birthday” with an in-product Easter-egg hunt of feature “presents,” designed to make users feel celebrated and emotionally connected.

topics.title: Staying close to users: users, non-users, and sales calls
topics.summary: Mihika shares practical ways to stay immersed: ask friends and peers how they use (or don’t use) the product, prioritize non-user insights to uncover perception barriers, and partner closely with sales by joining calls so customer pain points shape the roadmap.

topics.title: Operationalizing insights (partial, transcript cut off)
topics.summary: Lenny asks how Mihika captures and systematizes what she hears (cadence, repositories, tooling). Mihika begins explaining how insights get operationalized at Figma/ FigJam, but the provided transcript ends mid-answer.
